text: Hi folks, I have a question about Julia code executing sequence. I have a function “func” that consists of 3 functions. func1 creates a file; func2 modifies the file; func3 processes the file. If I call 3 functions sequentially in Julia REPL, it works fine. However, when I call “func” in Julia, it pops an error, which looks like func3 was called before func2 was finished.  How comes this happen? Any comments are appreciated.

elements.text: Hi folks, I have a question about Julia code executing sequence. I have a function “func” that consists of 3 functions. func1 creates a file; func2 modifies the file; func3 processes the file. If I call 3 functions sequentially in Julia REPL, it works fine. However, when I call “func” in Julia, it pops an error, which looks like func3 was called before func2 was finished.  How comes this happen? Any comments are appreciated.

text: Are you sure func2 finished execution? Have you flushed all accesses to the opened file/closed the file?

elements.text: Are you sure func2 finished execution? Have you flushed all accesses to the opened file/closed the file?

text: Good question! I’m not 100% sure (newbie here). But if I call the functions one by one and it works fine, I assume the files have been closed/flushed, right?

elements.text: Good question! I’m not 100% sure (newbie here). But if I call the functions one by one and it works fine, I assume the files have been closed/flushed, right?

text: I think probably runnuing them one by one induces enough latency that `func2` finishes before `funn3` starts. Probably something is happening asynchronously and needs to be locked.

elements.text: I think probably runnuing them one by one induces enough latency that
starts. Probably something is happening asynchronously and needs to be locked.

text: I found that, using `include`  to reload my program doesn’t work well all the time. e.g., I just added some `@info`  but the outputs didn’t change. what is a good way to reload the program you just revised? Thanks

elements.text: to reload my program doesn’t work well all the time. e.g., I just added some

text: If you're using include, Revise won't be able to track changes. You need `includet` for that

elements.text: If you're using include, Revise won't be able to track changes. You need

text: Or just put the code in a package and `using` it, then Revise should get everything

it, then Revise should get everything

text: `include` is fine if you just call it over and over again. It won't track them automatically.

elements.text: is fine if you just call it over and over again. It won't track them automatically.

text:
Not necessarily. For instance, if an old version of the file had a method
```f(x::Int) = x + 1```
and then later you change that to
```f(x::Integer) = x - 1```
and reinclude it, the original method won't be deleted, so whenever you call `f(1)` you'll get `2` instead of `0`.

elements.text: Not necessarily. For instance, if an old version of the file had a method
and then later you change that to
and reinclude it, the original method won't be deleted, so whenever you call

text: `include` is the same as writing the code into the repl by hand. But don't use if you want Revise to track changes to the file. Use `includet`.

No, when we say "track changes" we mean that as soon as you save the file, Julia knows what has changed and updates itself without you having to do anything.

Mason is probably better situated to help you debug this particular problem. I'm not sure whats going on entirely

text:
Nothing to apologize for, Feng. We’re here to help! Sometimes helping will involve telling someone we can’t help without a MWE, but that’s fine. 

Part of the purpose of this channel is to just nudge people in the right direction to figure out what’s going on when they don’t even know how to begin debugging.
